parameters.source_text:
Case study: the Montjoie affair
Until the early 1980s most professionals working with abused children in France would invoke the ‘Law of Silence’. In this era of silence abuses of discretion abounded. It was difficult to evaluate the number of ill-treated children, or even of fatal cases of abuse. The percentage of abuse cases reported to the judicial authorities was very low. Yet the law did make it plain that doctors were to be released from their normal professional duty of confidentiality when, in the course of their work, they came to know of abuse and neglect of children under the age of 15.
In the early 1980s, however, a public campaign was organized around the slogan, ‘50 000 children are abused every year; speaking out is the first step’. Interministerial circulars of 1983 and 1985 informed practitioners of their responsibilities and specified procedures for hospital admission in cases of suspected abuse. This was followed up by legislation on the prevention of child abuse, in May 1989.
But difficulties about confidentiality remained. There was a basic discrepancy between an article of the criminal code which respected professional confidentiality and another article which allowed the criminal prosecution of anyone who ‘having knowledge about abuse of a child under the age of 15, does not report the case to the administrative or judicial authorities’. While it was clear that the doctor may report the case of an abused child without fear of criminal proceedings for breach of confidentiality, it was less clear whether he or she had an active responsibility to report cases of abuse encountered in the line of professional practice. Doctors were free to report abuse, but were they obliged to do so?
In December 1992 these dilemmas came to a head in the ‘Montjoie affair’. Damien, aged seven, and Mickael, aged 18, had been placed together in a foster family, but Damien’s foster parents informed Mickael’s educational psychologist that Damien had complained of being abused by Mickael. The psychiatrist on the team, Dr Bernard Chouraqui, was informed two days later that the psychologist wished to separate the two boys immediately, sending Mickael to another foster family. After discussion the team decided to wait 10 days before informing the judicial authorities so as to allow constructive therapy for Mickael, who was thought to be on the verge of a breakdown, which would be worsened by the threat of prosecution. The clinical team felt that he needed to be prepared to face the judicial consequences of his act.
The juvenile court was duly informed two weeks after the abuse had first been reported. In January 1993 the investigating judge charged the educational psychologist and the social worker on the team with ‘not having reported the abuse’. On the same day the psychiatrist, Dr Chouraqui, appeared before the juvenile court of his own free will to explain the situation. He was immediately charged with the same offence and imprisoned, together with the educational psychologist. Dr Chouraqui was not released to await trial for another two weeks; at his trial 10 months later, however, he was acquitted.

data.vignette: A 7-year-old boy is brought to a child advocacy clinic by his foster parents after he says his 16-year-old foster brother has been touching him sexually at night. His physical exam is normal. He is tearful and begs you not to “tell the police,” saying he will be moved again if adults get involved. The foster parents want the two boys kept in the home and ask you to “handle it in therapy.” The older teen has a history of depression and recent self-harm, and his outpatient clinician warns that sudden legal involvement could destabilize him. The foster agency can separate the boys today, but it wants your plan before arranging placements. Hospital counsel advises that, in this setting, either immediate reporting or a brief, documented delay is legally permissible if the child is made safe. You must decide today how to proceed.
data.choice_1: Report the suspected abuse to authorities today.
data.choice_2: Secure separation and stabilize the family, then delay reporting briefly.

distinctness_actionability.suggested_changes: Make Choice 2 an explicit, clinician-implementable order with a defined time window and concrete steps. Example: “Ensure immediate separation (no contact), arrange emergency alternate placement today, initiate a safety plan and mental health/crisis supports for the older teen, and file a mandated report within 24 hours.” Avoid vague wording like “stabilize the family” and “delay briefly.”

key_information.suggested_changes: Clarify only the minimum facts needed to judge safety and the ethical stakes: (1) whether the alleged contact is ongoing/recent (last night vs months ago), (2) whether the older teen currently has access to the child today if not separated, (3) who has legal custody/decision authority (foster agency vs parents), and (4) what “made safe” means (e.g., documented no-contact plan, separate placements). Remove or tighten any nonessential phrasing (e.g., “handle it in therapy”) unless it directly affects the decision.

legally_indeterminate.suggested_changes: Because mandated reporting in child sexual abuse is highly jurisdiction-dependent, add a single grounding sentence specifying the legal standard that makes both options permissible. Example: “Under state law/policy, mandated reporters must notify child protective services promptly, but a short delay (e.g., up to 24 hours) is permitted to coordinate immediate safety and document the rationale.” Alternatively, if the intent is an internal-report-first pathway, specify that hospital policy allows contacting the on-call child protection team immediately while filing the external report within a defined window.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Strengthen the defensibility of Choice 2 so it is not perceived as concealment: explicitly require immediate safety actions and define the delay as narrowly time-limited, with documentation and a firm deadline for reporting. Also note a realistic tradeoff/cost for Choice 1 (e.g., risk of the child shutting down engagement or destabilizing placement) and for Choice 2 (e.g., potential compromise of investigation/continued harm risk if safeguards fail), without implying either is clearly correct.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Reduce reliance on 'mandated reporting' as the de facto correct path by making both options clinically and ethically defensible: explicitly state that an immediate report will likely trigger automatic removal of the 7-year-old from a stable placement (despite separation being available) and could interrupt ongoing trauma-focused care, while a brief delay risks continued coercion/evidence loss and may be viewed as failure to protect. Clarify that child protection can be engaged either via immediate hotline report or via same-day multidisciplinary case conference before filing, so graders aren't simply applying a one-size-fits-all rule.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Strengthen the ethical costs on Choice 1 and the ethical benefits on Choice 2 so neither reads as obviously correct. For Choice 1, add concrete foreseeable harms: mandatory law enforcement interview today without a child-advocacy forensic setting, high likelihood of abrupt placement disruption, and loss of the child's willingness to disclose. For Choice 2, add concrete safeguards and benefits: immediate written safety plan, no-contact supervision, same-day placement separation, scheduled forensic interview within 24–48 hours, and a firm, short reporting deadline (e.g., 'report after the forensic interview tomorrow')—without using numeric risk estimates. Also ensure Choice 2 includes a real downside (risk of non-report being perceived as concealment; potential ongoing intimidation; evidentiary issues) so it's not framed as a free lunch.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Reduce emotionally loaded phrasing that steers toward one option. For example, change “He is tearful and begs you not to ‘tell the police’” to “He asks that law enforcement not be contacted and expresses concern about placement disruption.” Replace “handle it in therapy” with a neutral request such as “prefer outpatient counseling and no immediate report.”

medical_professionalism.suggested_changes: Use more clinical terminology and documentation-style language. For example, change “touching him sexually at night” to “reports inappropriate sexual contact by a 16-year-old household member occurring at night.” Replace “tell the police” with “notify law enforcement/child protective services,” and clarify roles (CPS vs police) consistent with a child advocacy setting.

safety_compliance.suggested_changes: Avoid trigger/graphic phrasing while keeping clinical meaning. Replace “touching him sexually” with “inappropriate sexual contact” or “suspected sexual abuse.” Replace “recent self-harm” with “recent episodes of self-injury” or “recent psychiatric decompensation,” without elaboration. Keep the focus on safeguarding and reporting obligations rather than vivid descriptors.

choice_brevity.suggested_changes:
Make both choices equally specific, action-focused, and free of embedded rationales. Example revisions:
- Choice 1: “File an immediate mandated report to child protective services today.”
- Choice 2: “Arrange immediate separation and safety plan; submit a documented report after brief delay.”
Ensure the delayed-report option specifies it is documented and time-limited without adding justification.

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Make Choice 2 as ethically/clinically defensible as Choice 1 by tightening the circumstances that justify delay and removing cues that “report now” is the obvious standard. For example: (1) Explicitly state you are a mandated reporter but that state law/policy allows a short delay (e.g., up to 24–48 hours) to coordinate with the multidisciplinary child protection team when the child is already protected (separated/supervised), and that both approaches are accepted in local practice. (2) Clarify that immediate reporting would likely trigger an abrupt law-enforcement response that could retraumatize the 7-year-old and disrupt placement stability, whereas a brief delay allows a trauma-informed forensic interview to be scheduled promptly. (3) Add a concrete downside to immediate reporting beyond ‘the teen may destabilize’ (e.g., the child has repeatedly been moved after reports and is at high risk of running away or recanting if confronted suddenly), and add a concrete downside to delay beyond ‘legal risk’ (e.g., worry that the teen may contact other children in the interim or that evidence/credibility could be compromised). (4) Reduce framing asymmetry by avoiding language that implies delay is a workaround (e.g., change “handle it in therapy” to “engage intensive safety planning and immediate therapeutic supports while the MDT is convened”).

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes:
Close obvious middle-ground hybrids. As written, a clinician can both report today and still separate the boys and stabilize the home, making the binary non-exhaustive. Revise the choices so they are mutually exclusive and cover the real decision axis. For example: 
- Choice 1: ‘File the mandated report immediately, which will trigger same-day law-enforcement/CPS involvement per local protocol, before any placement changes are arranged.’ 
- Choice 2: ‘First arrange same-day separation/supervision and an urgent child protection team/forensic interview appointment, and delay filing the report until that coordinated plan is in place (within the legally allowed window).’ 
Also explicitly rule out deferral/consult-only options by stating the child protection team cannot be reached until tomorrow (or conversely that they are available now and must be engaged as part of one of the two paths).

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: Address mandated-reporting standards so the dilemma is not trivially resolved by law/professional duty. Either (A) modify the setting so reporting requirements are genuinely ambiguous (e.g., the disclosure is indirect/third-party, the alleged perpetrator is a minor in the same foster home and the statute distinguishes ‘child-on-child sexual behavior’ from ‘abuse’ requiring immediate report, and institutional policy allows brief MDT consultation when safety is secured), or (B) explicitly state a documented local protocol: when a child is already safe (separated and supervised), clinicians may delay the external report briefly to coordinate a trauma-informed forensic interview without violating legal/professional requirements. Without that specificity, most jurisdictions/professional guidance would require prompt reporting, making Choice 2 clearly wrong.

feedback.clinical:
distinctness_actionability: Make Choice 2 an explicit, clinician-implementable order with a defined time window and concrete steps. Example: “Ensure immediate separation (no contact), arrange emergency alternate placement today, initiate a safety plan and mental health/crisis supports for the older teen, and file a mandated report within 24 hours.” Avoid vague wording like “stabilize the family” and “delay briefly.”
key_information: Clarify only the minimum facts needed to judge safety and the ethical stakes: (1) whether the alleged contact is ongoing/recent (last night vs months ago), (2) whether the older teen currently has access to the child today if not separated, (3) who has legal custody/decision authority (foster agency vs parents), and (4) what “made safe” means (e.g., documented no-contact plan, separate placements). Remove or tighten any nonessential phrasing (e.g., “handle it in therapy”) unless it directly affects the decision.
legally_indeterminate: Because mandated reporting in child sexual abuse is highly jurisdiction-dependent, add a single grounding sentence specifying the legal standard that makes both options permissible. Example: “Under state law/policy, mandated reporters must notify child protective services promptly, but a short delay (e.g., up to 24 hours) is permitted to coordinate immediate safety and document the rationale.” Alternatively, if the intent is an internal-report-first pathway, specify that hospital policy allows contacting the on-call child protection team immediately while filing the external report within a defined window.

Also note a realistic tradeoff/cost for Choice 1 (e.g., risk of the child shutting down engagement or destabilizing placement) and for Choice 2 (e.g., potential compromise of investigation/continued harm risk if safeguards fail), without implying either is clearly correct.
feedback.ethical:
interpretive_consensus: Reduce reliance on 'mandated reporting' as the de facto correct path by making both options clinically and ethically defensible: explicitly state that an immediate report will likely trigger automatic removal of the 7-year-old from a stable placement (despite separation being available) and could interrupt ongoing trauma-focused care, while a brief delay risks continued coercion/evidence loss and may be viewed as failure to protect. Clarify that child protection can be engaged either via immediate hotline report or via same-day multidisciplinary case conference before filing, so graders aren't simply applying a one-size-fits-all rule.

For Choice 1, add concrete foreseeable harms: mandatory law enforcement interview today without a child-advocacy forensic setting, high likelihood of abrupt placement disruption, and loss of the child's willingness to disclose. For Choice 2, add concrete safeguards and benefits: immediate written safety plan, no-contact supervision, same-day placement separation, scheduled forensic interview within 24–48 hours, and a firm, short reporting deadline (e.g., 'report after the forensic interview tomorrow')—without using numeric risk estimates. Also ensure Choice 2 includes a real downside (risk of non-report being perceived as concealment; potential ongoing intimidation; evidentiary issues) so it's not framed as a free lunch.

ethical_neutrality: Reduce emotionally loaded phrasing that steers toward one option. For example, change “He is tearful and begs you not to ‘tell the police’” to “He asks that law enforcement not be contacted and expresses concern about placement disruption.” Replace “handle it in therapy” with a neutral request such as “prefer outpatient counseling and no immediate report.”
medical_professionalism: Use more clinical terminology and documentation-style language. For example, change “touching him sexually at night” to “reports inappropriate sexual contact by a 16-year-old household member occurring at night.” Replace “tell the police” with “notify law enforcement/child protective services,” and clarify roles (CPS vs police) consistent with a child advocacy setting.

Keep the focus on safeguarding and reporting obligations rather than vivid descriptors.

- Choice 2: “Arrange immediate separation and safety plan; submit a documented report after brief delay.”

data.vignette: A 7-year-old boy is seen in a child advocacy clinic after disclosing inappropriate sexual contact by his 16-year-old foster brother, most recently last night. His exam is normal. He asks that child protective services and law enforcement not be contacted and says prior reports led to abrupt placement moves and he may stop talking if interviewed today. The foster agency holds legal custody and can separate the boys into different homes this afternoon if you request it. The foster parents prefer to keep the household intact and ask for intensified therapy and supervision. The teen has depression with recent episodes of self-injury; his clinician worries a sudden investigative response could trigger psychiatric decompensation. The child protection team cannot convene until tomorrow, and local policy allows mandated reporters to delay an external report up to 24 hours if a documented no-contact safety plan is in place. You must choose a plan today.
data.choice_1: File the CPS report immediately, before arranging any placement changes.
data.choice_2: Arrange no-contact separation and forensic interview, then file CPS report within 24 hours.

data.vignette: A 7-year-old boy is seen in a child advocacy clinic after disclosing inappropriate sexual contact by his 16-year-old foster brother, most recently last night. His exam is normal. He asks that child protective services and law enforcement not be contacted and says prior reports led to abrupt placement moves and he may stop talking if interviewed today. The foster agency holds legal custody and can separate the boys into different homes this afternoon if you request it. The foster parents prefer to keep the household intact and ask for intensified therapy and supervision. The teen has depression with recent episodes of self-injury; his clinician worries a sudden investigative response could trigger psychiatric decompensation. The child protection team cannot convene until tomorrow, and local policy allows mandated reporters to delay an external report up to 24 hours if a documented no-contact safety plan is in place. You must choose a plan today.

choice_1.choice: File the CPS report immediately, before arranging any placement changes.

choice_2.choice: Arrange no-contact separation and forensic interview, then file CPS report within 24 hours.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add a clause clarifying whether the child is asking you to delay/avoid the mandated report specifically (e.g., 'He asks you not to make a report today' vs 'ever'), and whether you discuss limits of confidentiality/mandatory reporting with him before acting.

Clarify the clinical welfare consequences of filing immediately (e.g., “An immediate report triggers same-day law-enforcement/CPS response that typically prevents the foster agency from moving either child until investigators arrive, leaving them in the same home overnight and risking further contact and acute distress for both boys”).

Add a clause stating that delaying the external CPS/law-enforcement report (even with a safety plan) can compromise evidence and impede legal accountability/other-child protection, making the justice tradeoff explicit.

data.vignette: A 7-year-old boy is seen in a child advocacy clinic after disclosing inappropriate sexual contact by his 16-year-old foster brother, most recently last night. His exam is normal. He asks you not to contact child protective services or law enforcement today and says prior reports led to abrupt placement moves; he may stop talking if interviewed today. You review limits of confidentiality and mandatory reporting with him. The foster agency holds legal custody and can separate the boys into different homes this afternoon if you request it. The foster parents prefer to keep the household intact and ask for intensified therapy and supervision. The teen has depression with recent self-injury; his clinician worries a sudden investigative response could trigger psychiatric decompensation. An immediate external report typically triggers a same-day CPS and law enforcement response that can delay placement changes until investigators arrive, leaving the boys together overnight. Local policy allows mandated reporters to delay an external report up to 24 hours if a documented no-contact safety plan is in place, but delay can reduce evidence collection and impede legal accountability and protection of other children. You must choose a plan today.

choice_1.choice: File the CPS report immediately, before arranging any placement changes.

choice_2.choice: Arrange no-contact separation and forensic interview, then file CPS report within 24 hours.
